conclusion: Two particles, A and B, start from rest at the same time and place, moving in the same direction. Their motion is described by a velocity-time graph.
In a v-t graph, the slope of the line gives the acceleration at any given time.
When the slope is positive, the particle is accelerating. When the slope is negative, the particle is decelerating.
Particle A starts from rest, accelerates to a velocity of 2v0 at time t0, then decelerates to zero velocity at time 2t0.
Particle B starts from rest, accelerates to velocity v0 at time 4t0, then decelerates to zero velocity at time 6t0.

premise: Particle A decelerates from 2v0 at t0 to 0 at 2t0.
conclusion: The change in velocity for particle A is -2v0, and the time taken is t0.

premise: The change in velocity for particle A is -2v0, and the time taken is t0.
Particle B decelerates from v0 at 4t0 to 0 at 6t0.
conclusion: The change in velocity for particle B is -v0, and the time taken is 2t0.

premise: The change in velocity for particle B is -v0, and the time taken is 2t0.
conclusion: Deceleration a_B = -v0/2t0. Magnitude of deceleration |a_B| = v0/2t0.
The ratio of the accelerations of A and B during deceleration is 1:1.
